sentences.english: For some economies, China has been a lifesaver.
sentences.chinese: 对一些经济体来说，中国是一个大救星。

sentences.english: The vegetable skewer's saving grace is the Yakitori sauce.
sentences.chinese: 日式串烧的酱料可说是蔬菜串烧的救星。

sentences.english: Layers were and are a lifesaver for any marginally complex design.
sentences.chinese: 图层是一切较复杂设计工作的救星。

sentences.english: Is there a deus ex machina, a device that will rescue the rich world from its plight?
sentences.chinese: 有没有救星可以拯救富裕国家脱离现在的困境呢？

sentences.english: Power is the shackle to shackle itself while love is the emancipator to emancipate itself.
sentences.chinese: 权势是禁锢自己的镣铐，爱情是解放自己的救星。

sentences.english: At the DingShi himself and became the savior of the brothers.
sentences.chinese: 二毛反成了自己及丁氏兄弟的救星。

sentences.english: After so much dry weather, this rain has been the farmers' salvation.
sentences.chinese: 气候干旱了这么久，这场雨成了农民的救星。

sentences.english: After so much dry weather, the rain has been the farmer's salvation.
sentences.chinese: 天气干旱了这么久，这场雨成了农民的救星。

sentences.english: Gorilla dung could conceivably be the salvation of the planet.
sentences.chinese: 大猩猩的粪便说不定或许正是地球的大救星。

sentences.english: Your salvation lies in a moment-by-moment recounting of the minutiae.
sentences.chinese: 你的救星就是时时刻刻描述那些细枝末节。

sentences.english: Was Russian prisoner No. 7 actually the 'dead' diplomat who saved thousands of Jews during the Holocaust?
sentences.chinese: 俄国监狱的7号囚犯真的是大屠杀时犹太人的救星吗？

sentences.english: So, is recreational fishing going to be the saviour with the deteriorating, historical mariculture industry in Hong Kong?
sentences.chinese: 究竟悠闲垂钓会否是香港海水养殖业的救星？

sentences.english: But digital screeners won't necessarily be a savior either.
sentences.chinese: 但数字放映也不一定是救星。

definition: (one's) last straw to clutch at/one's last hope
to save sb's life/(interj.) Help!/Save me!
to be pleased beyond one's expectations (idiom)/overjoyed at the turn of events
to rescue/to help out of difficulties/to save the situation
Thank heavens!/Thank goodness that's worked out so well!
lit. to have one's hands bound and be unable to do anything about it (idiom); fig. helpless in the face of a crisis
